title: Lint against the use of ? in places where Err is expected

labels.name: A-lint
labels.description: Area: Lints (warnings about flaws in source code) such as unused_mut.

labels.name: C-feature-request
labels.description: Category: A feature request, i.e: not implemented / a PR.

body:
I did, this, got really confused trying to fix the "erroneous error" that was happening, and then laughed when I realized what I'd done.

Minimized code with a bogus error message:

```
some_option.ok_or::<Box<Error>>(Err(
            "Did not expect None here"
                .to_string(),
        )?)? 
```

However, my colleague made the same exact error independently and it still took me a minute to see it, so it may be worth linting against.

We knew that a `String` could become a boxed error, and independently tried to make it compile, and both ended up wrapping it in an `Err` and then using `?` which uh... immediately returns it before ever calling `ok_or` causing the function to always fail. What we wanted was 

```
some_option.ok_or::<Box<Error>>(From::from(
            "Did not expect None here"
                .to_string(),
        ))? 
```

It may be worth linting against things like this somehow, because it's really hard to spot if it happens. Even after I'd already been bitten by it, it took me a few minutes to spot it in his code.

I'm not sure how general it can be, but at a first glance if a function returns `Result<T,E>` and takes in an `E` as an argument linting against using `?` on the argument in the `E` position(s) may work. But if not, linting against the use of `?` in `std` functions like `ok_or` whose purpose is to construct an error works too.
